content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @lyse flawed is the right word, no harsh at all. Good reading, and thanks for supporting the possibility of convincing @prologic to switch to a database! :-D :-P

Anyway, even if I did, which I‚Äôm sure I did, it wasn‚Äôt intention to say that I hate all SQL database outright, but rather my inner rage in this case comes from developers far too often reaching for that shiny *SQL database (doesn‚Äôt really matter what it is), only to discover when you go looking under the covers at the source code and what data is being stored, accessed and manipulated, it could. have been done with a simple embedded KV store or even a SQLite database. But no, instead, you have to worry about this extra component ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

As a big proponent of self-hosting, I find this an anti-pattern.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @lyse flawed is the right word, no harsh at all. Good reading, and thanks for supporting the possibility of convincing @prologic to switch to a database! :-D :-P

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Where did I hate on SQL databases? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic not me mate, I asked as I was genuinely curious and as someone who only really knows SQL as far as databases go, I keep wondering what life is like on the NoSQL side of the fence üòÖ

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Maybe maybe not. Depends on what you‚Äôre doing I guess. For small things I find simple things are better anyway. KV, flat files, a log, etc.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @bender @prologic I've went further down - sometimes to seek something I've read and caught my attention at the time, othertimes to reference old threads in new ones. In this context, nothing is "too old".

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic not me mate, I asked as I was genuinely curious and as someone who only really knows SQL as far as databases go, I keep wondering what life is like on the NoSQL side of the fence üòÖ

a large part of this comes from experience, dealing with databases, and SQL many times in the past, and then eventually coming to the realizing that everything is basically key value, stores, bloom filters, trees*, tries and various types of indexes and caches.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic not me mate, I asked as I was genuinely curious and as someone who only really knows SQL as far as databases go, I keep wondering what life is like on the NoSQL side of the fence üòÖ

For me personally I find it far easier to reason about the data I‚Äôm dealing with, what forms it needs to take and what to do with it.

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I've never liked the idea of having everything displayed all of the time for all of history.

@eldersnake@we.loveprivacy.club Sorry, @lyse@lyse.isobeef.org just pointed out to me on IRC at some ungodly hour this morning (woke up for some reason) that all my arguments are flawed ü§£ Regardless of my experiences and reasoning, I prefer to use bitcask for most things ‚Äúdadtabase‚Äù(ish) and the ‚Äúright data structures‚Äù for things I‚Äôm working with, be-it a key/value store, in-memory hashmap, write-ahead-log(s), indexes, etc. Perhaps I find it more comfortable and easier to use lower-level libraires to solve the same kinds of ‚Äúdata‚Äù needs.
